6.text: It’s 1300 and Birmingham is a bustling town.

10.text: This tour will take you on a journey through the marketplace and the streets that surrounded it.

15.text: The very heart of the medieval town.

18.text: New research together with archaeological evidence has given us a unique and unprecedented opportunity

24.text: to create an accurate depiction of the town's medieval character.

30.text: This is Edgbaston Street which still exists today.

35.text: In 1300 this is where the tanning pits were located.

40.text: Tanning was one of Birmingham’s earliest and most important industries.

44.text: Tanners use animal skins to make leather, an essential material in the Middle Ages

49.text: used for making all sorts of goods not just belts and shoes but jugs and drinking vessels too.

56.text: You can see a tanner here stretching the skins.

60.text: One of the final stages in leather making.

63.text: But before he reached this stage the skins would have been soaked in a mixture of urine and faeces

68.text: amongst other things, making this by far the smelliest trade in town.

77.text: The medieval market was established in 1166 and took place every week outside St Martin’s Church.

84.text: The market was the life blood of the town bringing the whole community together.

90.text: Here you could buy food, pottery, cloth and metal goods.

94.text: But people didn’t just come here to shop.

96.text: It was a place to meet your neighbours to catch up on all the gossip and enjoy a spot of entertainment.

104.text: Look at the stilt walker here keeping the crowds amused while they haggle for a good bargain.

118.text: St Martin’s Church was perhaps the most important place in medieval Birmingham

122.text: and was located in the centre of the town.

128.text: everyone was susceptible to disease and infection which could strike at any moment.

134.text: Care for your soul and preparation for a righteous death were important considerations.

142.text: Here you can see the rector of St Martin’s saying a funeral mass for one of the townspeople.

155.text: In 1300 Birmingham was a very successful market town.

160.text: Here to make the most of this prosperity the lord of the manor is building more roads and houses in his deer park

170.text: This part of the park become known as Park Street another road that still exists today.

177.text: Birmingham has always been a hive of industry

181.text: even in the Middle Ages people's backyards were places of hectic activity.

185.text: Here you can see more tanning pits and

188.text: out on the edge of town another important industry, pottery making.

193.text: The wooden houses of the medieval town were at great risk from the dangers of fire.

198.text: So the kilns used to make the pottery were purposely built at a safe distance from the centre.

212.text: Now we move to the house of Roger le Moul.

215.text: He was the richest merchant in town and his courtyard house demonstrated his wealth and status.

221.text: We’re not quite sure how he made his money but there’s a good chance he was a cloth merchant.

227.text: And because of his importance in Birmingham this street was named after him

231.text: and became eventually known as Moor Street.

252.text: Everybody today knows the Bull Ring as Birmingham’s main shopping centre

256.text: but in 1300 it was something very different.

259.text: Back then it was a livestock market where people would bring cattle to sell.

265.text: Bulls were kept in rings or pens

267.text: and on busy market days animals would have been kept in pens on all of the available land

272.text: between St Martin's Church and the manor house.

275.text: Turning the town centre into a mud bath.

290.text: This is the biggest house in town and belongs to William de Birmingham, Lord of the Manor.

296.text: You can tell he’s a wealthy man because he has a moat around his manor house, a sign of great status after all.

303.text: You had to pay a lot of men to dig it which didn't come cheap.

306.text: Although the house is long gone the name lives on as Moat Lane just by Birmingham's wholesale markets.

314.text: The manor house looks a little bit like St Martin’s Church and that’s because it’s built from the same red sandstone.

322.text: Only very important buildings like churches and manor houses were made from stone in 1300.

328.text: And notice how the outer farm buildings which were lower status are wooden

333.text: just like the rest of the homes in the town.

336.text: Here you can see the town's mill.

339.text: Where the people would have paid to have their corn ground into flour.

343.text: Yet another source of income for the lord of the manor.

357.text: So thank you for joining us on our tour of medieval Birmingham.

360.text: Remember that you can see the model interactive on display at Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery

365.text: in the exhibition, Birmingham: its history, its people.

369.text: We look forward to seeing you very soon.
